Author: juwo
Content:
My suggestion?

Paul and Paul, Robert, Jessica (and whoever else): Try to help each of us, here at news.YC - those who arent part of the elite club of YC funded startups.

I dont see any of you helping any of us (those not in the club).

What if NOBODY were to apply to YC - would you have this fame and book sales and NY Times interviews? No.

You owe your institutional success to us. You are standing on our shoulders.

Furthermore, the structure of news.YC is not conducive to the rest of us helping each other. (Nevertheless, I can say I received valuable input from dpapathanasiou, goladus, npk etc., and I tried to provide the same to whoever asked).

You have an elite samurai school with yourself as the master and the rejects hanging from the outside gates trying to peer in.

You can do whatever you want. But if you are disliked, it comes with the territory.

I had an intriguing thought today: we come to resemble those we demonize.

You loathe Bill Gates (in my book, he has reformed into a saint), but his early interviews...

Author: pseudotim
Content:
Paul, regarding the statement

"I'd rather wait 6-12 months to see what you build, how successful it is, and how well your team executes, and then decide whether or not to invest."

doesn't this assume the angel investor has the option to invest in either the convertible debt seed round or wait and invest in a series A? Who says the entrepreneur is going to be as interested in the angel money comes series A, once the application is launched, momentum is underway and the deal is becomming more interesting to other investors? Is not one of the benefits of an early seed round to an angel, that of access to an exciting team and concept before they take off? And yes, if the team really executes and delivers a huge valuation come series A, the angel gets diluted. But they got in on a big opportunity with a discount, with a greater liklihood of participating again in series A. Maybe this isn't ideal from an investor standpoint, but isn't this still interesting versus waiting on the sidelines and potentially not particpating at all, if you believe in the idea?\n

Content: Or see http://www.google.com/intl/en/options/ . The point is, if you're not talking about games, Microsoft is basically irrelevant to the way that the majority of people use computers.

Author: Readmore
Content: That is a lot like the programming gui for the Lego Mindstorms system. It seems like a good way to get kids interested in programming if only to bridge them to working with actual code.

Author: brianmckenzie
Content:
Make a word replacement filter.

If someone is causing problems just word-filter their name into something embarassing. Or take a word they use frequently in their posts and word-filter it into gibberish.
